title: Running a local cluster (on-prem) requires a cloud service to be setup
body:
First, many thanks for this tool. Extremely useful.

I followed the [instructions](https://skypilot.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference/local/index.html) to set up a local cluster on a new machine. No issues have been encountered up to running `sky launch -c my-local-cluster ''` which returns `Cloud access is not set up. Run: sky check`. 

Running `sky check` lists that all cloud services are disabled.

Additional info:
- `sky status` returns:
    ```
    Clusters
    No existing clusters.
    
    Local clusters:
    NAME              USER  HEAD_IP  RESOURCES  COMMAND  
    my-local-cluster  -     -        -          -        
    
    Managed spot jobs
    No in progress jobs. (See: sky spot -h)
    ```
- At the moment, I'm using the same system user both as an admin for deploying the cluster and as a user for submitting jobs.

title: [Examples] Fix resnet family of examples
body:
Closes #2358.

Resnet examples (`resnet_app*.py/yaml`) were not working on master because `CUDNN_PATH` and `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` environment variables were not set correctly. Python examples also had issues with up local workdir.

Fixed by following [tensorflow docs](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#software_requirements) to setup envvars correctly. 

Tested (run the relevant ones):

- [x] `./format.sh`
- [x] `sky launch resnet_app.yaml --cloud aws`
- [x] `sky launch resnet_app.yaml --cloud gcp`
- [x] `sky launch resnet_app_storage.yaml`
- [x] `sky spot launch resnet_app_storage_spot.yaml`
- [x] `python resnet_app.py`
- [x] `python resnet_app_storage.py`
- [x] `python resnet_app_storage.py`

title: [K8s] Storage mounting requires privileged containers
body:
Our storage mounting (goofys, gcsfuse) is based on FUSE mounts. Using FUSE mounts in containers requires running containers with `SYS_ADMIN` [capabilities](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48402218/fuse-inside-docker), which may not be permitted on many clusters and may be seen as a security risk.

We currently create privileged containers:

https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/2b2a158c6730f605ca61bc8c4b051b278e3b7474/sky/templates/kubernetes-ray.yml.j2#L172-L175

We may need to reconsider this and allow only `COPY` or `C_SYNC` modes for Storages attached to SkyPilot clusters on Kubernetes. Creating this ticket to keep track of this issue.

title: Bug or feature: `--gpus A100-8:8` defaults to `A100-80GB:8` without warning
body:
Previously, we'd print something like this, if the specified GPU name is not producing an exact match:
```
» sky launch --gpus A10:8                               1 ↵
I 08-04 15:12:22 optimizer.py:985] No resource satisfying <Cloud>({'A10': 8}) on [AWS, Azure, GCP, Lambda, IBM, SCP, OCI].
I 08-04 15:12:22 optimizer.py:988] Did you mean: ['A100-80GB:8', 'A100:16', 'A100:8', 'A10G:8']
```

With master, `sky launch --gpus A100-8:8` doesn't exhibit this.

Need to bisect to see what's up.

title: [Core] SkyPilot does not work on certain ISPs
body:
Some ISPs block `raw.githubusercontent.com` by never timing-out the HTTP call. This results in SkyPilot getting stuck at fetching catalogs when you run `sky launch`, since it tries to poll our catalog URLs hosted on `raw.githubusercontent.com`. 

E.g., Reliance Jio, the largest ISP in India, blocks `raw.githubusercontent.com`. See: https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/42655. As a result, SkyPilot cannot be used by users on Jio.

title: Add support for conditional exclusion of features (specific to a cloud) during provisioning
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->
Some context and comments are in https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/pull/2293 which couldn't be reopened.

This PR adds a backbone to conditionally exclude some unsupported features in a cloud instead of raising an error if even one of the requested features is unsupported. It accomplishes this by maintaining a per cloud map of excludable features -> exclusion condition. During provisioning, if the exclusion condition is met for any of the requested features, it excludes that feature from the corresponding `check_features_are_supported`. As of now, this aims to address https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/2249

This is a proof of concept PR and I've tested in locally (only have k8s cloud enabled). If this is a direction that we want to proceed in, I can work on adding tests for it and running existing smoke/integration tests.

title: [K8s] Show reasons for provisioning failure in K8s
body:
Currently if provisioning on k8s times out (i.e., pod was pending for > TIMEOUT), we show a generic `RuntimeError: Errors occurred during provisioning; check logs above.`. The logs don't contain any information why provisioning failed.

We should surface errors by polling the state of the pod and the reason for it being pending before we timeout, and surface these errors to the user.

title: [Storage] Have IBM COS respect .gitignore and .git/info/exclude for uploading
body: Currently, IBM COS does not support the recently added feature in Storage, #2018, which makes uploading from local machine to cloud storage to respect `.gitignore` and `.git/info/excldue`. `get_dir_sync_command()` from `storage.py/IBMCosStore` class needs to be updated to support this feature.

title: [Bug] Running `sky cancel cluster_name job_id` with docker job doesn't stop job
body:
I've been using sky pilot to launch a lot of FastChat servers and I've noticed that the `sky cancel` command doesn't work super well with docker based jobs.

My jobs typically look something like:

```yaml
run: |
  aws ecr get-login-password --region $AWS_REGION | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin $AWS_REPO_URI
  docker pull $IMAGE_ID
  docker run --rm \
    -p 80:80 \
    --env CONTROLLER_HOST=${CONTROLLER_HOST} \
    --env CONTROLLER_PORT=80 \
    --env API_PORT=80 \
    $IMAGE_ID \
    ./run_openai_api.sh
```

Its very simple:
1. Get the image
2. Run the image with some arguments

Everytime I try to cancel the docker job with a command like `sky cancel cluster-name 1`, the sky job gets canceled but the docker container is still running on the instance.  I have to ssh in manually and run `docker stop container_name`.

Is this an issue in how i start the docker container? Or is it an issue with how skypilot (and Ray) try to cancel docker jobs?

title: Update minimal permission for open ports
body:
#2210 introduces the function to open ports on cloud.

We need to add requested permission in our document for minimal permission for AWS/GCP, we probably should add another item about the permission for opening the ports. https://skypilot.readthedocs.io/en/latest/cloud-setup/cloud-permissions/gcp.html#user

For GCP, we don't have new permissions; For AWS, we need to add `DeleteSecurityGroups`.

title: [Storage] Adding new storage mode CSYNC
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->
This closes #1862 

When using managed spot job for training, it's necessary to save the checkpoints in the cloud storage as we want the training to recover from the checkpoint when preempted. And this requires the application to store the checkpoints in the cloud storage. However, writing the checkpoints to a cloud storage mounted directory takes a long time, especially for large models like LLM, and this stalls the training becoming the bottleneck. 

To mitigate this issue, this PR adds a new storage mode, `CSYNC`, where it runs a daemon to run syncing commands periodically at the specified remote path. This way, the training application can write the checkpoints to an unmounted directory and the checkpoints get synced asynchronously., which makes the process much quicker.

When a cluster running sync command laucnhed by `csync` is attempted to be stopped with `sky stop`/`sky down`, then it waits until the sync is completed before proceeding to stop/down the cluster.

**Note:**

- Running `backend_utils.wait_and_terminate_csync()` within `cli.py/_down_or_stop()` can be implemented smoothly with storage info in cluster table's metadata. Will implement this in a separate [issue](https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/2278)
- `backend_utils.wait_and_terminate_csync()` does not support `autostop`/`autodown` yet. Will be implemented after this [PR](https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/pull/2248) is merged

**TODO:**
- [x] write `_execute_storage_syncs` to setup `mode: CSYNC`
- [x] Handle `sky stop`/`down`/`autostop`/`autodown` with `cluster`'s `metadata`
- [x] support for user specifying syncing interval in task yaml
- [x] write the continuous syncing as an independent tool
- [x] add sync command for s3 and gcs
- [x] add storage tests for `mode: CSYNC`

Tested (run the relevant ones):

- [x] Code formatting: `bash format.sh`
- [x] Manual test on running `CSYNC` mode
- [x] Manual test on running `CSYNC` mode on a subdirectory of a bucket as a `source`
- [x] Manual test to run `sky stop` on a cluster running sync command launched by `csync`
- [x] Test managed spot job with checkpoint directory in `CSYNC` mode to confirm if training recovers correctly from checkpoints.
- [x] Relevant individual smoke tests: `pytest tests/test_smoke.py::TestStorageWithCredentials` 
- [x] `pytest tests/test_smoke.py::test_aws_storage_mounts_with_stop --aws`

title: [Spot] Failed spot jobs do not have complete log in the `sky spot logs --controller`
body:
The current implementation tries to stream the logs for the failed spot jobs back to controller after the user program fails. However,  if the output is too long, the streaming will be interrupted in the middle, causing the error log not complete in the `sky spot logs --controller`.

This has been observed by many users.

To reproduce:
`sky spot launch task.yaml`

```
# task.yaml
run: |
  for i in `seq 1 1000`; do
    echo very long outputs
  done
  mkdir -p $HOME/data
  wget https://huggingface.co/datasets/anon8231489123/ShareGPT_Vicuna_unfiltered/resolve/main/ShareGPT_V3_unfiltered_cleaned_split.json  -O $HOME/data/sharegpt.json
  echo failed run
  exit 1
```


The output of `sky spot logs --controller` will be:
```
...
....... .......... .......... .......... 12%  104M 2s
(failed-run, pid=14930) (failed-run, pid=3781)  83350K .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... 12%  386M 2s
(failed-run, pid=14930) (failed-run, pid=3781)  83400K .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... 12%  401M 2s
(failed-run, pid=14930) (failed-run, pid=3781)  83450K .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... 12%  348M 2s
(failed-run, pid=14930) (failed-run, pid=3781)  83500K .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... 12%  376M 2s
(failed-run, pid=14930) (failed-run, pid=3781)  83550K .......... .........: Resource temporarily unavailable
(failed-run, pid=14930) Shared connection to 34.130.221.137 closed.
```

title: [k8s] GPU Support and fractional resources for Kubernetes
body:
Adds GPU support for Kubernetes clusters and allows Kubernetes SkyPilot clusters to be created with fractional resources (e.g., 2.5 CPUs).

How to use:
* **If on GKE** - Should work out of the box. Simply run `sky launch --gpus ...`
* **If on EKS or onprem** - Create an EKS cluster with `eksctl create cluster -f tests/kubernetes/eks_test_cluster.yaml`. To automatically label GPUs, run `python -m sky.utils.kubernetes.gpu_labeler`. Then run `sky launch --gpus ...`.

What's working:
- [x] Plumbing for requesting `nvidia.com/gpu` resources
- [x] GPU type selection for GKE
- [x] Convenience script to automatically label nodes with GPU types for EKS and onprem - `python -m sky.utils.kubernetes.gpu_labeler`
- [x] Toggle default image based on requested resources
- [x] Support for fractional resources

TODOs for later (will be filed as issues and deferred):
- [ ] GPU type selection for onprem GFD - blocked on finding a mapping of gpu name -> label.
- [ ] Use a lighter GPU image
- [ ] Docs for GPU support - will be included in #2324 

Tested (run the relevant ones):

- [x] Code formatting: `bash format.sh`
- [x] GPU tests: `pytest tests/test_smoke.py::test_job_queue`, `pytest tests/test_smoke.py::test_huggingface` on GKE GPU cluster
- [x] All Kubernetes smoke tests on EKS (incl. GPUs) `pytest tests/test_smoke.py --cloud kubernetes`

title: CLI: make `sky down/stop/start` default to a unique cluster if exists.
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Partially address #1877.

When I have only 1 cluster in `status`:

Previously
```
(py37) ~ » sky down
Usage: sky down [OPTIONS] [CLUSTERS]...
Try 'sky down -h' for help.

Error: `sky down` requires either a cluster name (see `sky status`) or --all.
```

This PR makes it so that `down/stop` defaults to it:
```
(py37) ~ » sky down                                                                                            2 ↵
Terminating 1 cluster: admin. Proceed? [Y/n]: ^CAborted!
(py37) ~ » sky stop                                                                                            1 ↵
Stopping 1 cluster: admin. Proceed? [Y/n]: ^CAborted!
```

When I have 0 cluster in `status`: this PR
```
(py37) ~ » sky down

Cluster(s) not found (tip: see `sky status`).
```

Same for `sky start`.

title: [Storage] Support for storage info in cluster table's metadata
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->
This PR resolves #1203.

Currently, when we run `sky stop <cluster-name>` on a cluster that has cloud storage mounted, the mounting will be lost when restarted with `sky start <cluster-name>` as the mounting command does not get ran. 

In this PR, I save the `storage_mounts` dictionary as a metadata in `cluster` table's `storage_mounts_metadata` when `sky launch` is initially ran. Then, this is loaded to be used to re-mount when `sky start <cluster-name>` is ran.

title: Fetch latest IP when refreshing cluster status
body:
Currently when we `sky status -r`, we only use the cached IP: https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/608d0c34ced75b881e5b35b36e416f56d2f685fc/sky/backends/backend_utils.py#L1840
One potential problem is when we interrupt the launching process before the handle is written back to the local database here: https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/608d0c34ced75b881e5b35b36e416f56d2f685fc/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L2658
We might not have any cached IP for a cluster with ray runtime launched, which should be in `UP` state.
Maybe we should try to fetch the node IP if no cached IP exists.
One related problem is #2304 takes advantage of this to keep a cluster without skylet daemon running in an `INIT` state. We should raise an error to notify users when this happens.

title: [TPUVM] Failed to launch TPU VM with new ssh key
body:
When `sky launch` a TPU VM with a new pair of ssh key, the provisioning seems failed to connect to the VM through ssh. ~~It might because the TPUVM does not support the metadata/ssh-key API we adopted in #2119~~. This means any new user or spot controller may not be able to connect to the TPUVM created. 

Update: The reason is that in our ray yaml template, we do not set the metadata when the TPU VM is used.

To reproduce:
1. `mkdir -p ~/.ssh/sky-key.bk; mv ~/.ssh/sky-key* ~/.ssh/sky-key.bk`
2. `sky launch --use-spot examples/tpu/tpuvm_mnist.yaml -y -c test-tpuvm2`

title: [k8s] Fewer CPUs available than are present on the node
body:
Kubernetes runs system services as pods (in `kube-system` namespace) that take up resources on each node. This results in fewer CPUs being available for tasks than are physically present on the node.

This creates confusion when a user tries to provision a task that tries to use all CPUs on a node. 

For example, on a GKE node with 2 CPUs, only 0.94 CPUs are available to be allocated. Rest are allocated to Kubernetes system services (required to run Kubernetes, e.g., DNS, metrics etc). You can see this when you run `kubectl describe nodes`:

```
$ kubectl describe nodes
...
Capacity:
  cpu:                2
  ...
Allocatable:
  cpu:                940m
  ...
```

If a user tries to schedule a 2 CPU task, the task will not get scheduled and provisioning will fail. 

We should investigate a fix: (a) Clarify this in docs (b) Reconfigure system resource requirements (hard) (c) offset SkyPilot tasks' CPU requests.

title: Fix redundant start of skylet
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

During the launching process, in https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/ca6d1e841875df290667cee02082ae7e2149126a/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L2624 we attempt to restart the remote skylet if the version is mismatched with the version file `sky.skylet.constants.SKYLET_VERSION_FILE`. However, the version file is not synced up or created in the remote VM, which means the `python3 -m sky.skylet.attempt_skylet` command will always restart the skylet. This PR removed the start of skylet in the `head_start_ray_commands` section inside `<cloud>-ray.yml.j2` file and let `python3 -m sky.skylet.attempt_skylet` to start skylet.

title: Syncing sometimes incorrectly skips syncing
body:
I sometimes end up in situations where my working directory does not get properly synced when using `sky launch` or `sky exec`, I don't have a reproducible example yet but I'm under the impression that this happens when I switch between different git branches, and when launching a job with files that have an older timestamp than what is located on the remote machine. I have not fully confirmed this yet, but I guess it is worth sharing with you, as you may have more clues as to what is happening. 

Looking at the [`rsync` documentation](https://linux.die.net/man/1/rsync), I realize that by default `rsync` looks at the timestamps when deciding to sync a given file or not. This is unexpected and can lead to confusion when switching between different branches with different versions of the same file. Is my understanding correct? Perhaps we should look at the checksum of the files instead?

title: [k8s_cloud] Ray pod not created under current context namespace.
body:
Hi @romilbhardwaj ,

I encountered an issue where ray pods and services are not created under the namespace defined in the current context (by defining it via `kubectl config set-context --current --namespace=<namespace name>`).

This PR seems to fix the issue under my environment. Can you please review it?
Thanks.

Please find below what I did:

`sky local up` # wait for kind to create skypilot cluster
`kubectl config set-context --current --namespace=test`
`kubectl create ns test`
`sky launch   ../tasks/hi.yaml` # very simple task that echoes

Ray pod and services are created under `default` namespace rather than `test`. The provision seems to hang since the secret is being created under `test` namespace.

Looking into it more, it seems that namespace of the current context is located under `context` key

e.g. in my kubeadm cluster

```
{'context': {'cluster': 'kubernetes', 'namespace': 'test', 'user': 'kubernetes-admin'}, 'name': 'kubernetes-admin@kubernetes'}
```

in my kind cluster

```
 {'context': {'cluster': 'kind-skypilot', 'namespace': 'test', 'user': 'kind-skypilot'}, 'name': 'kind-skypilot'}
```

title: Ops with auto-refresh should warn about clusters terminated on the cloud
body:
Currently, clusters terminated on the cloud (either manually, or preempted, or auto-downed) are only warned if they are caught in `status -r`, where we print "Cluster terminated on the cloud: xxx".

However, for the preemption case, user has run into the following:
- a preemption happened
- ran `sky logs <clus> 1` which prints
```
» sky logs dbg2 1
ValueError: Cluster 'dbg2' does not exist.
```
which is very confusing to the user. This happened because `sky logs` auto-refresh first without warning any cluster being terminated on the cloud. 
- After this, running `status` would no longer show the cluster, which makes the user wonder exactly what happened.

I reproduced the above with both `sky logs` and `sky queue`, and we should look at all ops with such auto-refresh. Repro:
```
sky launch --cpus 2+ --use-spot  --cloud aws -i60 --down -c dbg

- 'dbg' exists in status table, is UP
- manually terminate in console

» sky queue dbg
Fetching and parsing job queue...
ValueError: Cluster 'dbg' does not exist.
```

title: [Feature Request] Support passing env variables via a .env file
body:
When launching or starting a new job, env variables currently need to be embedded in the config file or passed in through multiple `--env` arguments.  In some setups, its more convenient to have multiple env variables in a `.env` file.  Much like Docker's support, it'd be nice to be able to do 

```sh
sky launch -c some-cluster --env-file .env my-job.yaml
```

Instead of having to write all the env variables each time.

This is probably fairly simple with support for reading values from the file using `python-dotenv`

title: Add support for conditional exclusion of features (specific to a cloud) during provisioning
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->
This PR adds a backbone to conditionally exclude some unsupported features in a cloud instead of raising an error if even one of the requested features is unsupported. It accomplishes this by maintaining a per cloud map of excludable features -> exclusion condition. During provisioning, if the exclusion condition is met for any of the requested features, it excludes that feature from the corresponding `check_features_are_supported`. As of now, this aims to address https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/2249

This is a proof of concept PR and I've tested in locally (only have k8s cloud enabled). If this is a direction that we want to proceed in, I can work on adding tests for it and running existing smoke/integration tests.

title: [k8s] Kubernetes environment variables don't show up in SkyPilot tasks
body:
## Background
Kubernetes automatically populates containers with environment variables for discovering services running in the cluster. [See documentation](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/services-networking/service/#environment-variables).

These look like:
```
# My custom service:
SKY_9DA1_ROMILB_RAY_HEAD_SSH_PORT_22_TCP_ADDR=10.96.70.90
SKY_9DA1_ROMILB_RAY_HEAD_SERVICE_HOST=10.96.67.126
SKY_9DA1_ROMILB_RAY_HEAD_PORT_10001_TCP_PORT=10001

# Service to connect to Kubernetes API server:
KUBERNETES_SERVICE_HOST=10.96.0.1
KUBERNETES_SERVICE_PORT=443
....
```

These variables can also be seen when you `kubectl exec` into the pod. Applications running inside the pod use these environment variables to get the IP address and ports of services they need to connect to. 

## Problem
In SkyPilot, these environment variables do not show up when you run a task (e.g., `sky launch -- printenv`) or when you ssh into the cluster.

This may be problematic for users trying to run SkyPilot tasks that connect to other non-SkyPilot services running in the Kubernetes cluster. 

Our code also runs into this issue when we try to call `load_incluster_config()` to setup kubernetes auth, since it uses the `KUBERNETES_SERVICE_HOST` and `KUBERNETES_SERVICE_PORT` variables.

Note that this is likely not going to be a problem for multi-node support, since we will take care of populating the `SKYPILOT_NODE_IPS` environment variables, which can then be directly used by users. 

## Workaround
For now, we can ask users to use the [DNS discovery mechanism](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/services-networking/service/#dns) instead of envvars. This is also how we workaround for making `load_incluster_config` work.

body:
User story:
- I was testing out https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/a04f327021191820fe21eea5329ce2224951d951/llm/vicuna-2/README.md#kick-start-the-training-on-any-cloud which asked the user to enter a bucket name, without specifying `store` (S3/GCS/R2)
- After the task starts running, I want to look at the bucket -- but I am not 100% sure which object store it's created on
- So I want to use `sky storage ls` to check its location. However, this prints a ton of buckets, and I had to `sky storage ls | grep ...` to find it.
- It'd be better to `sky storage ls my-bucket`. Same as `sky status my-cluster`.

cc @landscapepainter 

---

NOTE: `sky storage ls my-bucket` now sounds like it's a cloud-agnostic ls (list bucket contents). Maybe ok for now but worth keeping in mind. Perhaps we should rename to `sky storage status`.

title: Minor: require pyyaml > 3.13 to avoid an error.
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

<= 3.13 may encounter https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/issues/414.

Tested `pip install -e`:
```
Collecting pyyaml<=5.3.1,>3.13
  Downloading PyYAML-5.3.1.tar.gz (269 kB)
     ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━ 269.4/269.4 kB 4.2 MB/s eta 0:00:00
  Preparing metadata (setup.py) ... done
```

Note however at the end
```
kubernetes 26.1.0 requires pyyaml>=5.4.1, but you have pyyaml 5.3.1 which is incompatible.
Successfully installed pyyaml-5.3.1 skypilot-1.0.0.dev0
```
which means our k8s support seems to conflict with the explicit `<= 5.3.1` pin. @romilbhardwaj

title: [SkyServe] `sky serve` CLI prototype
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

This PR introduces `sky serve` CLI for starting a service.

Currently supported CLI:
* `sky serve up <task_yaml>`
* `sky serve down <service_name>`
* `sky serve status (<service_name>)`

To see the log of control-plane, use `sky logs <controller_name> 1`;
To see the log of redirector, use `sky logs <controller_name> 2`.
You can find the name of controller by `sky serve status -a`.

TODO: Maybe have a `sky serve logs` CLI.

![serve-cli-example](https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/assets/74357442/599ae1b6-7902-453e-b558-30976bde51d5)

![serve-result](https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/assets/74357442/fec2d147-4d80-444f-916d-0e4c00e1f00d)
(The IP shown in the browser is the actual replica's IP)

title: Support Machine Image on GCP
body: [Machine Image](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/machine-images) on GCP is an easy-to-use functionality that lets a user create an image from a VM. I believe this is one of the few functions that GCP does better compared to AWS. Supporting this should benefit many GCP users!

title: [llm] Add clouds to llama2 readme
GCP: ~0.5 min longer provisioning time & a conda error
body:
For #2271: did a bisect which revealed that #2241 (95fdb5b21a87bb3a5) is the first commit that caused two problems:

1. ~0.5 min longer provisioning time, GCP T4
2. a conda error within the setup phase caused the above (conda attempting to send a crash report, then timed out)

Repro
```
sky launch --gpus T4 --cloud gcp -t n1-standard-2 -y --zone us-central1-b --down
```

title: Failure to reuse an existing machine and long provisioning time
body:

The job eventually launches, proceeds as expected and at the end ```console W 07-19 14:46:53 backend_utils.py:2185] Detailed reason: Found 2 node(s) with the same cluster name tag in the cloud provider for cluster 'gpu-small-testing-vm', which should have 1 nodes. This normally should not happen. Please check the cloud console and fix any possible resources leakage (e.g., if there are any stopped nodes and they do not have data or are unhealthy, terminate them). ``` I already terminated the duplicated nodes, but each new pipeline recreates a new machine. I'm not sure if the issue comes from GCP or SkyPilot on this one. Thank you for your help or your insight!

title: Usernames containing "." causes launching tasks on GCP to fail
body:
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/9b07ffc27cf8462c26aa359c4bf053e7d25aedcf/sky/templates/gcp-ray.yml.j2#L39

```I 07-19 14:54:23 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1700] Launching on GCP australia-southeast1 (australia-southeast1-a)
I 07-19 14:54:35 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:730]
Got googleapiclient.errors.HttpError:
<HttpError 400 when requesting https://compute.googleapis.com/compute/v1/projects/alana-skypilot/zones/australia-southeast1-a/instances?alt=json returned "Invalid value for field 'resource.labels': ''.
Label value 'alana.huang' violates format constraints.
The value can only contain lowercase letters, numeric characters, underscores and dashes.
The value can be at most 63 characters long. International characters are allowed.".

Details: "[{'message': "Invalid value for field 'resource.labels': ''.
Label value 'alana.huang' violates format constraints.
The value can only contain lowercase letters, numeric characters, underscores and dashes.
The value can be at most 63 characters long. International characters are allowed.", 'domain': 'global', 'reason': 'invalid'}]">
```


Trying to use sky launch to create a new cluster on gcp, but my username contains a "." which is an invalid character for the gcp labels. I do not want to change my username, so can skypilot provide an option to overwrite the user field used in the gcp labels?

title: TPU: `down --purge` failed to purge a non-launched TPU pod in invalid zone
body:
Tried provisioning a TPU pod in `us-east1-d`:
```
resources:
  cloud: gcp
  region: us-east1
  zone: us-east1-d
  use_spot: true

  accelerators: tpu-v3-128
  accelerator_args:
    runtime_version: tpu-vm-base
    tpu_vm: true
```
This failed with
```
I 07-18 20:57:31 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1704] Launching on GCP us-east1 (us-east1-d)
I 07-18 20:57:46 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:733] Got googleapiclient.errors.HttpError: <HttpError 403 when requesting https://tpu.googleapis.com/v2alpha1/projects/1234567/locations/us-east1-d/nodes?nodeId=ray-sky-xxxxxxx-head-xxxxxx-tpu&alt=json returned "Location us-east1-d is not found or access is unauthorized.". Details: "Location us-east1-d is not found or access is unauthorized.">
```
which is expected.

However,
```
» sky down sky-136e-zongheng    -p
Terminating 1 cluster: sky-136e-zongheng. Proceed? [Y/n]:
sky.exceptions.ClusterStatusFetchingError: Failed to query GCP cluster 'sky-136e-zongheng' status: WARNING:  Python 3.5-3.7 will be deprecated on August 8th, 2023. Please use Python version 3.8 and up.

If you have a compatible Python interpreter installed, you can use it by setting
the CLOUDSDK_PYTHON environment variable to point to it.

ERROR: (gcloud.compute.tpus.tpu-vm.list) PERMISSION_DENIED: Location us-east1-d is not found or access is unauthorized.
```
which is unexpected -- `--purge` should bypass this. At this point, no node was launched and this cluster is stuck in my cluster table requiring manual cleanup.

title: [SkyServe] Add service schema and change to new service YAML
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

This PR adds a schema checking for our newer version service YAML, and change to new YAML config pattern.

An example:

```yaml
service:
  port: 8082
  readiness_probe:
    path: /health
    timeout: 1200
  replica_policy:
    min_replica: 1
    max_replica: 5             # optional
    qpm_upper_threshold: 10    # optional, if qpm is higher, scale up
    qpm_lower_threshold: 1     # optional, if qpm is lower, scale down
```
